THE MAILS NORTH

We referred last week to the question of the change proposed by the Reginal Mail route by taking a view therefrom of the C. P. R., i. e., Prince Albert. We compared the distances between Regina and Prince Albert and Qu'Appelle and Prince Albert, and found the cost of carrying mail by other routes.

We showed that the difference in distance was only four miles at most, and that the cost would be greater from Regina than from Qu'Appelle. Would there not then be a change proposed at present? It seems very clear, except that the people of Regina are desirous of bringing grist to their own mill. The circumstances are not so powerful in this regard as they are in the trans-missouri route. There are settlements along the present route for at least one hundred miles that would require an independent mail service of its proper character-are affected thereby far past the point that post office beyond. The leader is now in its fourth year and I defy any one to find a single sensation conjuring up more mail business for any one along any of the branches of which have been brought in, particularly with the telegraph route. They could not have more vuolence. They would naturally infer from your article that you are assaill ague, latterly, as to duplicate service over this route.

Rapid City Ripples.

PRESENTATION.

On the evening of the 3rd inst., the trustees of Rapid City Mission presented Mr. Pinard, methodist minister and parishioner, with a beautiful silver pectoral accompanied with a very encouraging address, which was replied to in suitable words by Mr. Pinard's host and thankfulness. A very pleasant evening was spent in music, address, joking, etc., preceded by the guardianship of Mr. Geo. Huston, steward of the apportionment and recording steward of the circuit.

CONSUMPTION CURED.

An old physician, retired from practice, having been placed in his hands by a friend, made several experiments on powders. A vegetable remedy for the speedy and certain cure of Consumption was found. A leaf was used to make a decoction, which cured many cases. It may be used as a substitute for the French or English cure, with advantage. The use of the leaves has already been tried, but the results have been good. It is recommended with advantage at this juncture.

SATTLEFORD.

Mr. Easie, formerly Indian Agent at Fort Macleod, went to the agency at Biggar, Manitoba. His numerous friends will regret his departure from this place.

A day patrol of police examines the animals of all straggling Indians and squaws found about town, and gives them their passes without the necessary document of option of returning to the reserve or leaving the back-pan. They always prefer to go together.

TOUCHWOOD.

TO THE EDITOR:

Sir)—In a paragraph which appeared this morning in the paper you expressed yourself freely on the improvement in Touchwood. We thought this was a very unnecessary step for you to take, as you are right in calling on the day school at our signal on Moderator's recommendation is canonical and the establishment of a Sunday school pleasing to all who are interested in the education and proper upbringing of the children. We think also that you are mistaken in your statement that this gentleman and other so-called clubbers make such a noise as to disturb others by holding occasional services for them. As far as we know there is only one missionary in the church of England who has done this for the last three or four years, and that is Rev. J. F. Wright, as Lay Reader by the Bishop of Episcopal Church, who lives in Touchwood. It is either at the Past or in the Plain, performing the duty you attribute to another. During all the summer months no attempt is made by the teacher to ensure an effective service; she would be happy to take my directions and attend Sunday; but under present circumstances the question is impracticable.

I am Sir,

yours etc,

TOUCHWOOD.

Missionary at Touchwood Hills Round Plain. March 12th 1886.

Moffat.

ON Tuesday evening the Sabbath, a large number of the youthful young folks responded to an invitation from Mrs. Moffat, and as they came rather late there was considerable lapse of time before they could be heard in the chapel when they came in the daytime. Mrs. Moffat desired that they should be counted and the result being so splendid for Niapissings, Sandilands and Alland Heads districts. Dinnings was kept late, and the whistles and calls for the evening meal presently appeared to enjoy themselves immensely. Refreshment was served at six o'clock and the dinner in which they enjoyed themselves immensely. Afterwards they gathered around the fireplaces rendering "Blue Bells of Scottland" and that was considered an evening not to be forgotten.

QU'APPÈLLE

—Local correspondence on fifth page.

Mr. Mr. John Irving has returned from the east.

—A number of immigrants have arrived here Monday.

—Walshley news correspondents will appear next week.

—Walshley news crewed out by Walshley men today.

—Seeking new cornerstone by song in this district on Monday.

—A book of wild geese went everywhere northward on Tuesday.

—Mr. Mr. Beaumont's posts in front of his new store are just the thing.

The Dominion Government has been sustained by a majority of 90 on the Riot question.

—Mr. Mr. L. D. B., director of Winnipeg, who will shortly visit Qu'Appelle.

—Mr. Mr. Lovell and some of his friends arrived here this week. I thought he would give a good talk.

—Mr. E. Shore has brought the Commissary boat to Mr. Cass Macdonald, late of British Columbia.

—Owing to receiving Walshley mill bonus bay late we are compelled to hold over a quantity of lumber.

—A year ago today the 39th Battalion of Winnipeg, arrived here instead of going east (this was before the Rebellion Act), being ordered from the camp to suppress the rebellion.

—Mr. Walter Blackburn of the Laytor farm had a valuable goat stolen a few weeks back while going west on Tuesday night.

—Eleanor Shoemaker has become engaged to Mr. McMillan.

—Mr. H. McMillan & Co.'s mill has not been running in the last few days as some alterations are being made in the engine house.

—Postal service is speedily established at Wind is drugs that the letter signed "H. J." in today's proceedings last week was correct.

—Mr. Mr. Dyson informed us that letters delivered by mail are now being answered promptly during the week.

—The return game of cricket was played here on Tuesday between Indian Head and Qu'Appelle clubs, resulting in favor of the latter by a score of 14 to 11.

—The Methodist Sunday School will hold a quarterly session on Sunday morning by-half past fourteen o'clock (2:30 p.m.), at which special inviters is given.

—Rev. T. Lawton, Methodists, and Rev. John Macdonald, United, exchanged pledges on Sunday having is pleasing to see a fraternal spirit prevail even in churches.

—10th Battery, formed into two divisions to-day. Wheat and fish shrimps about two miles from town. A number of our citizens looked within the maneuvers.

—Messrs. F. Thomson and Steinhauser of M. F. Baly & Son, are to go to Regina on Tuesday to attend a replaying run respecting some stock which formerly belonged to the Graham family estate.

—Parties contributing to Tiny Volunteer Corps, requested five companies. They gave this opportunity to men willing to meet for the Battalion. They have heard since they promised to meet every Tuesday evening at the Fort, and will appear here again next week when they will undoubtedly draw a crowd of listeners.

—On Thursday of last week, Messrs. J. Ajhorne Ouviet and H. Miana, Rebellion Losses Commissioner, visited Qu'Appelle, proceeding north to Prince Albert, where the opening of a school will be joined by Mr. Trefethen.

After adjoining upon the claims of local settlers there they proceeded to Fort Saint James, where they returned to consider the list of settlers in this vicinity. It will take about three months to complete their labor in the north.
